title: 110_hr4051
content:
The "Housing Assistance Authorization Act of 2007" prohibits the use of authorized funds for lobbying purposes. Additionally, it provides assistance for the National Urban League. The Housing Assistance Authorization Act of 2007 prohibits the use of funds for lobbying and authorizes grants to the National Urban League for providing technical and financial assistance to local non-profit organizations for community development and affordable housing projects serving low- and moderate-income households, especially in neighborhoods with African American income-disadvantaged populations. Assistance includes site acquisition, development, construction financing, and leveraging capital from private entities. The Housing Assistance Authorization Act of 2007 authorizes grants to the National Urban League for providing technical and financial assistance to local non-profit organizations for community development and affordable housing projects serving low- and moderate-income households, including African American households. Private financial institutions, insurance companies, and philanthropic organizations can also provide support. The Secretary and the National Urban League may determine additional activities. Authorization of appropriations includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. SEC. 4. Assistance for Raza Development Fund. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant funds to the Raza Development Fund for providing assistance to local non-profit organizations in community development and affordable housing projects for low- and moderate-income households, especially in neighborhoods with Hispanic populations. Assistance can be used for site acquisition, development, construction financing, and leveraging capital from private entities. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development authorizes grants to the Raza Development Fund for supporting local non-profit organizations in community development and affordable housing projects for low- and moderate-income households, with a focus on Hispanic populations. The funds can be used for various activities, including technical assistance, training, and financial support. Authorization of appropriations includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. SEC. 5. Assistance for the Housing Partnership Network. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant funds to the Housing Partnership Network to support affordable housing and community facilities for low- and moderate-income households. The Network can use the funds to invest in member nonprofits and entities to leverage private capital for housing development and sustainability. The Housing Partnership Network can use granted funds to invest in member nonprofits for housing development and sustainability. Funds can be used for production capacity, sustainability, efficiency, necessary expenses, and other activities as determined by the Secretary and the Network. Authorization of appropriations is set at $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. SEC. 6. ASSISTANCE FOR NATIONAL COMMUNITY RENAISSANCE. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant funds to the National Community Renaissance Program for affordable housing projects benefiting low- and moderate-income households. The funds can be used for site acquisition, rehabilitation, leveraging capital from private entities, and other determined activities. Authorization of Appropriations for grants under this section includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. SEC. 7. AUDITS AND REPORTS.

The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the financial transactions of entities receiving funds under this Act and submit reports to relevant committees. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the use of funds appropriated to these entities over the past 10 years. SEC. 8. PERSONS NOT LAWFULLY PRESENT IN THE UNITED STATES. Prohibits the use of funds under this Act for direct housing assistance to individuals not lawfully present in the United States.
